The Four Gospels and the Q Source

When we look at the gospels of Matthew and Luke we can see clear parallels. Mathew and Luke used Mark's work as a basis for their own, which explains the similarities. Matthew's gospel contains 90% of Mark's work. Luke's gospel contains 50% of Mark's work. This would likely mean that Mark was the commonality of this work.

But how about the other ten percent of Matthew's gospel and the other fifty percent of Luke's gospel that didn't derive its information from the Marcan Source (Mark's gospel)? Scholars have postulated that there is a 2nd source that Matthew and Luke used to get the material to write their gospels. The basis is a hypothetical document called "Q." "Q" is the abbreviated form of the German word "Quelle" and means "source."

There are only two narratives in Q: (1) Jesus' struggle with the devil (Luke 4.2-13; Matthew 4.1-11); and (2) the healing of the centurion's slave (Luke 7.2-3, 6-10; Matthew 8.5-13). But even both of these stories focus more on Jesus' words, than on the events concerned. 

If this concept is given some weight, then much of Q has a social context, showing a better way of living than the early Christians knew in their own lives. As we know from Paul's later letters, by around the year sixty-five, Christians started wondering if Jesus would come back as many had predicted. This makes a date for Q of later than sixty-five yrs. less likely. Some think that the story of the fight with the devil in Q is talking about an incident in 39 when there was a mass demonstration against the putting up of a statue of the Emperor Caligula in Jerusalem [1]. If that's what it is, the Q material likely was created after that time.

The Q material in Matthew and Luke is set in differing contexts, but in roughly the same order. This is a strong argument against those who (like Michael Goulder [2]) have decided that there was no Q source and that Matthew and Luke either came from this material from elsewhere or wrote it themselves. The very similar sequence strengthen the conclusion that Luke and Matthew weren't using unique sources, but the same one.

One example is:

So also Mark 8.34-35 is used in Matthew 16.24-25 and Luke 9.23-24. A Q version also shows up in Matthew 10.38-39 and Luke 14.27 & 17.33.

Overall, many suggest that Luke's version of Q better represents the original more accurately than Matthew's. The conclusion that Q has been as a lost to time written source of some sayings of Jesus has stood firm after more than a century of testing with amazing strength. 

If one accepts that Q is a now-lost written record of "what Jesus really said", then 'Q' can be considered as a long-missing record of the words that Jesus supposedly said.

·We must also accept the process used to analyze the gospel texts. We know about Q largely because many hundreds of scholars have torn the gospels apart down to their bare bones. The specifics have been and will continue to be discussed. But the overall approach has lasted the test of time.

A number of further assumptions can be validly drawn from the evidence [4]:

·The material within Q indicates that it had high status in the early Jewish-Christian communities centered around Northern Galilee. They turned to it for guidance in life-issues.

·Each of the four gospels (excluding Thomas) were designed to get across a particular theological theme. Q is not like that. It is a collection lacking coherence. It lacks literary plan and is fundamentally un-edited.

·Those who are not familiar with the scholarly work of the past 20 years may react to Q with some unhappiness. This makes sense. We have, in the gospels, not a magically-created hand-me-down from God via an undefinable process of revelation, but a truly human impression (rather than a record) compiled in a normal way for those times. 

Our knowledge today about Jesus is therefore subject to all the strengths and limitations of normal human processes by which information is conveyed from person to person.

How To Determine The Purpose For Your Life

Your Purpose is Unfolding Each Moment of Your Life

To pay attention to what comes naturally.

·Trust that you'll be provided with what is necessary for you to perform your "business."

·Love others even as God has loved you. Love they neighbor as thyself. What these sayings teach is that your main mission in this life is to perfect the ability to love. 

Unfortunately, humans tend to try to make things much more convoluted than that. Most of us have at least 4 simple ideas about what we tend to think of as "life missions."

Our unique purpose in life or our mission exists somewhere "out there" and is just awaiting our discovery of it. 

Most feel that we probably need to do "something" to change ourselves in order to find our mission, or to become deserving of accomplishing our life mission.

Our original goal, known as our Birth Vision, is why we are searching in the 1st place. 

One experiences a sense of intuition as those brief "gut-feelings" or vague hunches. As we consider these feelings or sensings more seriously, we become familiar with them, and we are able to grasp the nature of these intuitions more clearly, and to see how they very often guide us.

Your Internal Motivation

The 1st step is to recognize that your mission exists within you in the form of your natural inclinations, instincts, desires and what encourages you. Reading, playing hopscotch, writing, coloring, etc.

Just for fun, take a piece of paper and write down all the activities that you did as a child or that now brings you pleasure as you think of them. For instance, if you liked doing crossword puzzles, take it one step further. Ask yourself what it is about crossword puzzles that you find so much fun that you'd spend your days doing them. Was it because you worked them by yourself in a quiet environment, giving you plenty of time to ponder and to look words up in a dictionary?  Perhaps you have a terrific memory, or have an amazing ability to choose the right word. Or maybe you get a real sense of joy and accomplishment, a feeling of closure when you complete a puzzle. All these things are motivating factors making this activity deeply worthwhile to you then, and maybe even now.

One does not need to "wait" to find your life's purpose. As you look, so shall you discover.

The future is still to come, and while we can plan for it, we do so with the understanding that we really do not know what it will bring, or if there is even a future!

Tips On How To Get Rid Of Your Hurt
 
 
Today's discourse reviews the concept of forgiveness. I am going to discuss seven awareness exercises to help you in getting rid of the old anger, the pain, and the distraction that carrying around a grudge can do.

 
The 1st technique is an 'awareness' exercise.
 
1. Think about what gave you the discomfort. Was it something said, something you or someone else did to you, one thing not mentioned, not completed, not felt, what? What was it that lit the fuse?
 
Two. The next thing is to ask of your inner self WHY it brings about in you pain. Was a confidence betrayed? Had you been rejected on some levels? Have your hopes been dashed? Consider the way that hurt shows itself.
 
3. Think about or let your emotions to go in the direction of the person who ‘did‘ this. From where was it coming? What buttons had been pushed on his/her end? Why did it happen?
 
Four. Imagine yourself in that particular person's shoes. Have you ever actually done anything at all similar? Could you possibly picture, allowing for what you already know of their life, at any time doing something equivalent? Are you capable of, without condoning what they've done, maybe recognize it a little? Have you actually cut another person off on the road? Have you previously spoken without considering your words or stated a thing that were uttered not as intended?
 
5. Ask yourself what your role in the predicament was. Might you have been reacting out of some of one's personal emotional wounds? Might there have been a thing you mentioned or did that possibly induced the other human being's hurt? Would you have done something in a different way if you'd identified the outcome?
 
Six. Take accountability for your individual role. Would it be wise to apologize? Are you able to forgive yourself? Take a seat, close your eyes and envision a soap bubble in front of you. Put your discomfort inside the bubble – all of it – and encourage it to float out of your space. When it's away from your immediate space, destroy it.
 
Seven. Pray for The Divine Force to help you. Invite The Divine Force to shine a golden ray of forgiveness onto you and also the other people included.
 
Your job this week is to check out the parts in your everyday life in which you're withholding forgiveness.
 
Do the activities to discharge your grudges and give yourself the reward of forgiveness through this <a href="http://www.ulcseminaryprogram.blogspot.com">Spirit Quest</a>.
 
Treat yourself well all week.

You area perfect being.

You were created

for perfection.

What Can I Say When Someone Dies?

You'll find quite a few strategies you can use in which families, friends might be helpful to those they know that are grieving. 
 
In the process of determing the help needed of your heart-broken loved one, it helps to comprehend the circumstances surrounding the death.  You can find gigantic contrasts within the grieving manner that greatly depends upon the age of theperson who died, the manner of death. (For example, was it a unexpected death, or did it come after a lengthy sickness  
 
Avoid Clichés
 
"He is out of pain now," "It was her time," and "All things always work out for the higher good," are aren't helpful.  Keep in mind, there are no prepared phrases which will remove the emotional discomfort of the loss.
 
Phrases To Avoid:
 
"Time heals all wounds." (Time by itself does not make everything better, though it can help.  Those who are grieving do need time, but at the same time they need to experience the various stages of grief.
 
"Be gladyou've got another child." (This minimizes the importance of the one who died.)
 
Good Things to Say:
 
"You must have been very close to him." (The bereaved can then share about the relationship.)
 
Don't Think That You Are Expected To Have "Something to Say."
 
Your presence is enough.  Especially with new grief, a hug, your touch and your genuine compassion are all that the mourner may possibly need. Make it a point to call or visit the survivor, regardless of how much time has passed since the death.  Your caring will be greatly appreciated.
 
Take the Initiative
 
Don't merely say, "If there's anything at all I can do, you can always ask." Make suggestions as well as specific things you can do.  As an example, you might say, "I would like to tend to your yard next Sunday morning at (pick a time.  Would that be a good time for you?" or "May I go grocery shopping together with you the first time out?"  Each thoughtful gesture reminds the bereaved he or she is not alone and keeps him/her from having to continually reach out for assistance. It also lets your friend know you believe he or she continues to be important. Our self-esteem can be often low during the early months of the grieving process, as well as feeling that someone is caring enough to help does good things for the morale.
 

 
Offer To Help With the Kids
 
If children are involved, they would appreciate it if you would send them special notes now and again and invite them on trips along with your family. Children really should also deal with their grief, but sometimes they need a break from the sadness at home, while their parents may appreciate some time for grieving privately.  Show your caring along with support and ask them to share their ideas as well as their emotions.  They need excellent listeners, also. Do not make the assumption that a person who seems calmness is fine.
 

 
Enable the Expression of Guilt Feelings
 
A healthy reaction to hearing someone express grief can be to respond with by saying, "It's not your fault.  There was nothing you could've done."  Don't try to rescuepeople from their guilt emotions, because are healthy and normal when people are grieving.  (What most people feel is likely regret.  Guilt implies they did something on purpose to cause injury; we more likely feel regret when we wish we might somehow been able to adjust things.)
 
Permit the Survivor to Grieve In His/Her Own Way
 
Avoid pushing the mourner to "get over" the loss.  If he needs to work out at the gym or lift weights to let go of penty up energy and tension, let him.  If she needs to to go through old photos or read every book on grieving he can locate, allow her. 
 
Allow For Mood Swings
 
Assume good days and bad days for quite awhile. These highs along with lows are a normal part of the process.  These feelings have been described as waves that sweep in uncontrollably.

Step by step the very good days turn out to be a lot more frequent, but bad days will occur as much as a year or more after the passing of a loved one.
 
Remember That Recovery Takes Time
 
Don't make the assumption that the mourning person to be "over it" within a couple of weeks.  Great waves of emotion may well pour through for several months and then, slowly, progressively, the emotional storm subsides.  It doesn't happen a immediately after the <a href="http://www.ulcseminaryprogram.blogspot.com">memorial service</a> or even 2 months after it, as many individuals think. 
 
Talk Openly About the Deceased
 
During the first several months after a death, there's a tendency to focus on those left behind, while the survivors themselves are putting attention on the person who died.  By Sharing your memories about the deceased, you're giving a special gift to the mourning person.  Your caring and your concern are clear in not only by the things that share, but in the fact that you simply took the time to do so.

Finding Your Spiritual Self

I've been thinking about what it means to be spiritually awake and have not yet figured out what that means.  I have been going from one Internet site after another looking for information that will explain exactly what spiritual awakening is all about.
 
The nearest I came to discovering an answer talked about being a Christian and all that has to it.  But, being a Christian is only a very small part of what it means to be spiritually awake.  One site talked about the attributes of a spiritually awake person in a paper titled "The Purpose of Life is <a href="http://www.ulcseminary.net">Spiritual Growth</a>".  I can agree with this statement but still it is only a title to a paper.  The paper talks about the fact that there are 2 types of people in this world. 

How many of you would describe yourself as being a materialistic person with all the characteristic of that kind of a person?  Very few of you I'm sure, but do you not display those kinds of attributes from time to time?  You could say, "I'm only normal" and you are.  We all present to the world both kinds of mannerisms and we are both materialistic and spiritual people. Some of us believe that we are more spiritual than the other, and that's OK.
 
Now, what can we do to become totally spiritually awake? Well, I think that the description above of the spiritual-minded person tells all.  We can be that kind, generous and loving person we claim to be 24/7.  It only takes a little mindfulness to make it so.  Keeping in mind those attribute that make us a spiritual person.
 
I want to be a totally awakened spiritual person and I want you to awaken also.  We can change this world from being totally materialistic to be spiritually oriented world in 2012.  2012 will be a year of change, a transitional world into the higher aspects of the spiritual life.  You and I can be a part of that.  We only have to make up our minds to be so by promoting to the world that we are indeed a spiritually awaken person.

All of the above questions about spirituality have their answers in a positive "yes". True spirituality has its place in everything we do, day in and day out. We are all spiritual beings here on this earth and it is one of our goals to find God and practice his teaching in the best way we know how. We are here to search the "scriptures" to find the teachings that best express our spiritual understanding and to evolve spiritually.

Throughout the history of Man, there have been a number of men and women who have come into this world to show humanity that there is a better path. A better way to look at our life: and a better way to solve our problems so that we understand them and act accordingly.

<a href="http://www.ulcseminary.net">Spirituality</a>; is something that is being discussed about throughout the world. It is a very big part of people's conversations. It is talked about on radio and television. It is written about in articles, books, magazines and newspapers. Spirituality is something that is a bit of a mystery for us because we don't have anyone to show us how to be spiritual. Being spiritual is within us. No-one can show us what it is. We all experience it in our own way and it shows up in our lives. I know that I have not solved the question for some of you, but the fact is spirituality is in the ways we practice our faith and belief in the God. –Rev. Ron Koch

Start Learning About Your Purpose In Life

Your Purpose is Unfolding Each Moment of Your Life

To pay attention to what comes naturally.

·Trust that you will be provided with what is necessary for you to perform your "business."

·Love others even as God has loved you. Love they neighbor as thyself. What these sayings teach is that your main job in this life is to perfect the ability to love. 

Unfortunately, humans tend to try to make things much more involved than that. Most of us have at least 4 common ideas about what we tend to think of as "life missions."

Life's purpose is something very specific – a namable job or thing for us to do. 

Because of the uncertainty of this named occupation or idea of what we are supposed to be doing, we end up saying, "I'm so confused. I've no idea what my life mission is (or supposed to be).  I simply don't know what I'm good at; I'm only a (insert current job here) and that does not have any real importance.

What this searching is all about is trying to recall our original intention or our Birth Vision. 

Suddenly our focus changed to the afterlife dimension, and here we could see clearly that our goal the whole time was not merely to create a New Earth, but a New Heaven as well. (The Tenth Insight)

Your Internal Motivation

Start by looking at those things you love to do. What things to do you that bring you your joy and satisfaction?  What did you do for hours on end when you were a child? Reading, playing hopscotch, writing, coloring, etc.

As an experiment, take a sheet of paper and jot down all the activities that you did as a child or that now you enjoy as they occur to you. Do this exercise with each interest and talent you have and look at why you like it so much! If you work in alignment with these motivations you realize that you are living a part of your life purpose. You may not want to make your living solving crossword puzzles, but the some part of that activity – words and their meanings are something that you are inherently attracted to. Study how your ability can translate into something you can bring outward and into your daily life. Watch carefully to what and where your attention is drawn.

Discovering and <a href="http://www.onlineseminary.net">Living Your Purpose</a> as a Process.

The next step is in understanding that purpose is a namable occupation. Generally, the majority of people think that our purpose will be based on a career, such as becoming a teacher, a doctor, a real estate agent, a dental hygienist, the vice-presidency of marketing, a social worker, <a href="http://www.ulcceremonies.com">becoming a ULC minister</a>, or an interior designer. You might wish to consider that your purpose is really to learn to be more caring in your reaction to all beings. Perhaps your purpose is to mentor one special child, to create an industry, or to be the Rock of Gibraltar to your family or others who are in your life. By understanding that your life purpose is revealed over the course of your entire life journey, your world can be opened to welcoming all that comes to you as a part of your purpose, not just your day-to-day job and stuff that gets you through your day. Another area in comprehending your life purpose is to realize that you may have more than a single "life purpose" over the course of your entire life, as the circumstances of your life change, or things and people in your life grow over time.

For some reason, a lot of us are under the impression that until we discover our life purpose that life is on hold or is insignificant. The present moment is actually the only moment you have to fully touch and to be touched by life. The past is gone, and while we can change the effects of our past on our current and future life, we cannot change or redo any of the actions we did or neglected to do.

What Exactly Is the Q Source and How Does It Relate To The G

When we look at the gospels of Matthew and Luke the parallels are abundantly clear. That is due to the fact that Matthew and Luke drew upon Mark for most of their gospels. Matthew's gospel contains ninety percent of Mark's work. Luke's gospel contains 50% of Mark's work. This would likely mean that Mark was the commonality of this work.

But how about the other ten percent of Matthew's gospel and the other 50% of Luke's gospel that didn't derive its information from the Marcan Source (Mark's gospel)? Bear in mind that the Q source is a hypothetical document that has been discovered by scholars weaving together the similarities between the gospel accounts of Matthew and Luke that cannot be credited to Mark. Scholars have meticulously resurrected this work as a unique source attributing the accounts that Matthew and Luke use outside the Marcan source.

There are only two narratives in Q: (1) Jesus' struggle with Satan (Luke 4.2-13; Matthew 4.1-11); and (2) the healing of the centurion's slave (Luke 7.2-3, 6-10; Matthew 8.5-13). But even both of these stories focus more on what Jesus said, than on the events concerned. 

The four main gospels seem to think less about Jesus coming again, and more about what they call the "Kingdom of God". There is a well-supported argument for assuming that by "Kingdom" they meant letting God's sovereign rule be the guidelines in their thinking about life and the context of the times when they lived. As we are aware from Paul's later letters, by roughly the year sixty-five, Christians had begun to wonder if Jesus would come back as some had predicted. This makes a date for Q of later than sixty-five years less likely. Some believe that the story of the fight with Satan in Q refers to a situation in 39 when there was a huge demonstration against the putting up of a statue of the Emperor Caligula in Jerusalem [1]. If true, the Q material likely came into being after that date.

Mark's Gospel has no Q material but is used as an obvious reference by both Luke and Matthew. Strikingly, it appears that the source represented in Mark's gospel is the same Q version used by both Matthew as well as Luke.

One example is:

Mark 4.25 is used in Matthew 13.12 and Luke 8.18. A similar version from Q also occurs in Matthew 25.29 and Luke 19.26.

Overall, many suggest that Luke's interpretation of Q preserves the original more accurately than Matthew's. Some reasons why the discovery of Q is so important should be summarized in the conservative light of those who question the accuracy of the information we have about Jesus, and the fundamentalists who believe each written word as ‘gospel' so to speak. 

If one agrees that Q is a now-lost written record of "what Jesus really said", then 'Q' should be considered as a long-missing record of the things that Jesus actually said.
